div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: F UZZY logic control has been proposed as an effective ap- proach for complex nonlinear systems. The Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy system is one of the most popular fuzzy systems in the model-based fuzzy control [21]. By using a T-S fuzzy plant model, one can describe a nonlinear system as a weighted sum of some simple linear subsystems. This fuzzy model is described by a family of fuzzy IF-THEN rules that represent local linear input/output relations of the system. The overall fuzzy model of the system is achieved by smoothly blending these local linear models together through membership functions. Therefore, the last decade witnessed a rapidly growing interest in T-S fuzzy systems, and many important results have been reported in [2], [3], [7], [10], [13], [17], [21]- [24], and references therein. Specifically, the stability analysis and stabilization are studied in [2], [3], [10], and [13]. The control problem is investigated in [6], [8], [20], and [22]. The filtering problem is addressed in [24].

On the other hand, the study of stochastic systems has been of great interest since stochastic modeling has come to play an important role in many branches of engineering applications [9]. Many results on stochastic systems can be found in the literature. To mention a few, the control problem is studied in [18] and [28].
The filtering problem is investigated in [14], [26], and [27], and the model reduction problem is considered in [29].

Over the past decades, the fault detection problem has received much attention [1], [5], [12], [15], [19], [30], [31]. The basic idea of fault detection is to construct a residual signal and, based on this, determine a residual evaluation function to compare with a predefined threshold. When the residual evaluation function has a value larger than the threshold, an alarm of fault is generated. Since accurate mathematical models are not always available, the unavoidable modeling errors and external disturbances may seriously affect the performance of model-based fault detection systems. To overcome this, fault detection systems have to be robust to such modeling errors or disturbances. A system designed to provide both sensitivity to faults and robustness to modeling errors or disturbances is called a robust fault detection scheme. Recently, H ∞ theory has been applied for control and estimation problems in order to improve the unknown input attenuation capability [4], [6], [14], [20], [26], [28]. H ∞ fault detection problem has also been reported; specifically, Gao et al. [5] study the robust fault detection under missing measurements; Qiu and Gertler [19] consider robust fault detection based on H ∞ optimization; Jiang et al. [12] investigate H ∞ fault detection filter design for discrete-time systems with multiple time delays; Zhong et al. study fault detection for uncertain linear time-invariant (LTI) systems [30] and Markovian jump systems [32].

Motivated by the fact that the fuzzy set is an effective way to describe a nonlinear system, in this paper, we will investigate the robust H ∞ fault detection for a class of nonlinear Itô stochastic systems, which can be modeled as a T-S fuzzy linear Itô stochastic system (a weighted sum of some simple linear stochastic subsystems). Research in this area should be interesting yet challenging as it involves the combination of two classes of important systems, namely, stochastic systems and fuzzy systems. It should be pointed out that, so far, there have been only a few papers that have taken the stochastic phenomena into account in the fuzzy systems [11], [25]. Also, there are few research results reported on the fault detection of the Itô stochastic system.

We will consider an Itô stochastic system with a Brownian motion in this paper, which is different from the general stochastic system. Hence, for the robust fault detection problem, there exist totally an external disturbance, a fault signal, and a Brownian motion in one system. Therefore, how does the Brownian motion affect the fault detection process and how to detect the fault signal from such a complicated system are unexploited research problems that need to be investigated. In this paper, we shall solve the fault detection by designing a detection filter that generates a residual signal to estimate the fault signal. The main aim is to make the error between residual and fault as small as possible. The detection threshold of the filter is also discussed, and simulation is performed to illustrate the efficiency of the proposed approach.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The H ∞ fault detection problem is formulated for T-S fuzzy Itô stochastic systems in Section II. Section III gives our main results. A numerical example is provided in Section IV, and we conclude this paper in Section V.

Notations: The notations used throughout the paper are standard. The superscript "T " stands for matrix transposition; R n denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space; P > 0 means that P is real symmetric and positive definite; I and 0 represent the identity matrix and a zero matrix, respectively; (Ω, F, P) is a probability space with Ω the sample space, F the σ-algebra of subsets of the sample space, and P the probability measure. E{•} denotes the expectation operator with respect to probability measure P; L 2 [0, ∞) is the space of square-integrable vector functions over [0, ∞); trace(•) denotes the trace of a matrix; • denotes the Euclidean norm of a vector and its induced norm of a matrix; diag(. . .) stands for a block diagonal matrix. In block symmetric matrices or long matrix expressions, we use a star ( ) to represent a term that is induced by symmetry.

Typically, fault detection schemes are concerned with the construction of a dynamical system called a residual generator. This auxiliary system takes the known input and output of a system and generates a signal called the residual. This signal is then processed to decide whether or not a fault has occurred in the system [32]. Therefore, a typical fault detection system consists of a residual generator and a residual evaluation stage including an evaluation function and a prescribed threshold. In this paper, for the plant represented by ( 1) or (2), we consider the following two kinds of fault detection filters.

1) Fuzzy-rule-independent filter: In the case that the premise variable of the original fuzzy model θ(t) is unavailable in filter implementation, the filter structure will have to be independent of the fuzzy rules. div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the robust H ∞ fuzzy fault detection has been studied for a class of nonlinear stochastic systems. Both the fuzzy-rule-independent and the fuzzy-rule-dependent fault detection filters have been designed. Sufficient conditions have been proposed to guarantee the mean-square asymptotic stability with an H ∞ performance for the fuzzy stochastic fault detection system. Then, the corresponding solvability conditions for desired fault detection filters have also been established. A numerical example has been provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed theory. Here, we use θ to represent θ(t) for simplicity. figure.figDesc: Filter Design for Itô Stochastic Systems With Application to Sensor Fault Detection Ligang Wu and Daniel W. C. Ho, Senior Member, IEEE Abstract-The paper deals with the robust fault detection problem for Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy Itô stochastic systems. Our aim is to develop a robust fault detection approach to the T-S fuzzy systems with Brownian motion. By using a general observer-based fault detection filter as a residual generator, the robust fault detection is formulated as a filtering problem. Attention is focused on the design of both the fuzzy-rule-independent and the fuzzy-ruledependent fault detection filters guaranteeing a prescribed noise attenuation level in an H ∞ sense. Sufficient conditions are proposed to guarantee the mean-square asymptotic stability with an H ∞ performance for the fault detection system. The corresponding solvability conditions for the desired fuzzy-rule-independent and fuzzy-rule-dependent fault detection filters are also established. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed theory. Index Terms-Fault detection, filter design, H ∞ performance, stochastic systems, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy systems.
